msDesc.head: A: Ortolf von Bayrlandt, Hugh of St. Victor, etc.; B: the 'Oxford Boethius', etc.; C: theological collection. Germany, 15th century, middle

supportDesc.extent: ii + 375 + ii leaves (fols. 81, 285, 318, 319, 326 are doubles, fol. 213 is treble) 210 145

binding.p: Later brown leather quarter covers over original wooden boards, five bands. Latch marks on the upper and lower covers, latch lacking.

history.provenance: Dating and localisation based on watermarks and content. All parts were bound together in the last quarter of the fifteenth century, in the same region where they had been produced. See Daniela Mairhofer (2017) p. 208–09.

Medieval provenance not known; not identifiable in the late-fifeenth-century catalogue of the Erfurt Carthusians, or the 1783 catalogue of the Benedictine abbey of St Peter in Erfurt, but later ownership by Bülow (see below) may well suggest Erfurt provenance, and the manuscript may have reached the Carthusians after the catalogue was compiled.

Friedrich Gottlieb Julius von Bülow, 1760-?1831 (?): almost certainly identifiable as 382 in the catalogue of his sale, 1836: 'Tract. de mysteriis ecclesiae, de virtutib. etc. - Apocalypsis. - Quatuor novissima. - BOETIUS De consolat. philosoph.'
history.acquisition: Presented to the Bodleian Library by his sons and received in 1857.

recordHist.source:
Description adapted by Tuija Ainonen and Matthew Holford (April and Dec. 2020) from the following sources (with additional description of contents and provenance): Daniela Mairhofer, "Bodleian Library, MS. Hamilton 46. 'Der Oxforder Boethius. Edition und Studie'," Oxford German Studies 46 (2017) 206–212. [contents, dating] Unpublished description by Stephen Mossman, c. 2003. [contents, dating]
Summary Catalogue, Vol. 5, p. 33 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 5, p. 34

ref.title: Handschriftencensus: Eine Bestandsaufnahme der handschriftlichen Überlieferung deutschsprachiger Texte des Mittelalters

msItem.note: Fol. 1r, contents list to the whole volume, but not including fols. 1v-13v, followed by verses ('Dat vinum purum septem tibi commoda...') and note 'Gloria patri propter tria. Primo quia nos creavit...'.

msItem.author: Ortolf von Baierland
msItem.title: Arzneibuch
msItem.note: (excerpts)
msItem.incipit:
Vrina rubea et spissa significat sanguineam complexionem
Vrina rubea et tenuis significat colericam complexionem
msItem.explicit: Ossa magna xxx digitorum xv pedum 39 peditarum xv
msItem.note: It retains blocks of the German original, and is interpolated with extracts from other sources, notably the Latin ‘Secretum Secretorum’. German passages are located at 1v, lines 16–20, and 2r, lines 1–21 and 39–42. (Mossmann c. 2003, unpublished description).

msItem.title: Medical and dietary calendar: rules for the months
msItem.incipit: In Januario de optimo vino ieienus bibe, sanguinem non minue

msItem.title: Alphabetical index to art. 4.
msItem.rubric: Sequitur registrum seu tabula alphabetica in librum sequentem super Hugonis dydascolicon

msItem.author: Hugh of St. Victor
msItem.title: Didascalicon
msItem.note: (excerpts)
Alphabetical index to the remaining folios of part 1 (fols. 'xxxvi' to 'xlv).

msItem.author: Hugh of St-Victor
msItem.title: De meditatione
msItem.incipit: nobis ad meritum proximis ad exemplum
msItem.note: PL 176.993–8, here beginning imperfect at 995B.

msItem.title: Life of St. Catherine of Alexandria, in verse
msItem.incipit: Durch dye Junffer katheryn moße got gelobet syn gode vnd er czü eren wyl ich myn synne keren an er lyden vnd leuen vnd dar van kuntschafft geuen Er dye iunffer waz geborn waz sye van gode erkorn
msItem.explicit: Sye beden vyel gode a/en Sye yrren alle myt eyn ed en yß nicht dan eyn got alleyn des werke syn alle ding dye ynne hayt der werlde ring all
msItem.note: In the hand of a later scribe, this is a German addition between two short, theological pieces; it is in a late 15th century cursive script, in brownish-black ink, and is but poorly legible. It consists of 157 verses of the first part of a lengthy ‘Conversio’ narrative, with the ‘Nativitas’ section added, and is therefore a German text within the ‘Conversio I’ group of Latin verse narratives. This text is in a version not attested in either conspectus of Lives of Catherine of Alexandria: cf. Williams-Krapp, Werner, Die deutschen und niederländischen Legendare des Mittelalters, Texte und Textgeschichte 20 (Tübingen 1986), pp. 425f., and Assion, Peter, ‘Katharina von Alexandrien’, Verfasserlexikon 4 (Berlin and New York 1983), pp. 1055–73. (Mossmann c. 2003, unpublished description).

msItem.title: Medical text
msItem.incipit: Nota bene si aliquis homo perdidit scientiam et sensus

msItem.rubric: De signis mortis corporalis et spiritualis
msItem.incipit: Primum signum mortis corporalis si naros [?infurim] contrahunt
Sex sunt deuia que nos a via vite seducunt scilicet obliuio dei

msItem.title: Sermon (?)
msItem.incipit: Visus et aspectus aliquarum creaturarum effectum habet in creaturis. Basiliscus enim solo aspectu
msItem.explicit: Istos septem oculus quod agnus occisus habebat conuertat et digerat ad nos per multitudinem miserationum suarum qui venit et regnat deus benedictus in secula amen.
msItem.note: Perhaps cf. München, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Clm 28602, fol. 127ra.

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: In illa die erit fons patens In istis verbis propheta duo facit primo commendat divinam largitatem
msItem.note: Followed by short texts on the orders of angels ('Angelus est primus...'), on the three arks ('Temporibus tres esse tribus...), , on metals ('Septem sunt nomina metallorum...').

Various notes and verses: on the Annuciation ('Hec est dies illa dominus quem fecit in ista...'); mnemonic for the order of the gospels ('Purpura cenat...'); on the ages of the world ('Incipiens ab adam quem...', WIC 9182); grades of consanguinity; 'Eusebius dicit in cronica...'; WIC 2058 (Urban V, 'Balsamus et munda'); WIC 11550 (Pius II (?), 'Misticus agnus').

msItem.title: On the conception of the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: Qui portum salutis wlt apprehendere dei gentricis creationem et conceptionem dignis obsequiis debet celebrare

msItem.title: 'Libellus de tribulacione'
msItem.incipit: Quia per multas tribulationes oportet nos intrare in regnum dei Actus 14 considerandum est scriptum in presenti libello de tribulacione
Adam post peccatum maximam tribulationem passus est de paradiso expulsus
msItem.note: Note at the end: 'Residuum quere in aliis duobus foliis...'.

physDesc.p: Made up of two codicological units, fols. 1–14 and fols. 15–60.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., c. 39–42 lines . Written space c. 185–195 120

msItem.note: Boethius, De consolatione philosophiae, with glosses, commentary, and partial German translation. Edition by D. Mairhofer forthcoming, June 2020.

msItem.title: Commentary on Boethius, De consolatione philosophiae
msItem.incipit: Felicitas est summum bonum finale et ultimum primo ethicorum In qua quidem propositione 4 ad presens sunt probanda. Primo quod felicitas sit bonum

(fol. 61v) Carmina qui quondam
liber cuius subiectum est consolacio philosophica diuiditur
libros parciales

msItem.title: De consolatione philosophiae
msItem.note: (German translation: the 'Erfurter Boethius' or 'Oxforder Boethius')

Translated into German are sporadic sections (fols. 115r–139r) of book 3 (that is p. 1, m. VIII, and p. 9), book 4 as a whole, and book 5, with the translation breaking off at fol. 211r (5. p. 4, 31). (D. Mairhofer, "Bodleian Library, MS. Hamilton 46. 'Der Oxforder Boethius. Edition und Studie'," Oxford German Studies 46 (2017), p. 206 n. 1)

Two Latin colophons within the German text allow us to date the translation to 1465. On fol. 132v we find: In die beate Margarete [13th July], vere margarite, preciose gemme, que castitate niuea et candida est, expositum uel translatum est istud metrum. deo gratias. On fol. 202v, we find: Datum in die solis in die dominica post Michaelem [6th October] anno domini mºccccºlx quinto in Buchen. deo gratias. Gaudeat creatura in terra quia semper videtur oculis misericordie adulcissimo creatore. 'Buchen' is likely, given the other place-names to be found in this manuscript, to be one of the three small towns named ‘Buchen’ in the region immediately north and north-west of Siegen. (Mossmann, c. 2003).

msItem.locus: (fol. 148r, inserted leaf, upper half torn off:)
msItem.title: Letter, seeking a loan
msItem.note: An added leaf to allow the addition of a Latin text (on the verso), mentioning ancient gods, probably relating to the Boethius text which surrounds it. On the back of this leaf (on the recto), is preserved part of a letter in German to the anonymous author’s younger brother, asking for a loan. It contains a considerable amount of autobiographical information and mentions the abbey of Flechtdorf, between Paderborn and Siegen, in Westphalia. It is in a very similar hand and style as the Life of Catherine of Alexandria text in the first manuscript above. (Mossmann, c. 2003).
msItem.incipit: waß ich eyn monich worden wye ich anderß czü dem ewigen leuen komen vnd ys myn wylle gewest dat ich wolde czü Flechtorff czien in sunte benedicteß orden vnd was och noch myn wylle dar yn han gegeuen so moß ich dar yn
msItem.explicit: dat dü yn eym dage kanst gedayn vnd wan du by myr werst wolden wyr czu hauff reden des vns große not ys pro be dat beste

msItem.title: Life of Peter Denrich
msItem.note: (incomplete)

The free space at the bottom of fol. 220r is filled with a text in a hand very similar to that of the Life of Katherine of Alexandria text in the first part above. The text continues into the margin on the left hand side of the leaf. (Mossmann, c. 2003).

Between the large stub of 222v and the pasted-in leaf that is 223 are a series of five small stubs, evidently full leaves that have been roughly cut out. On the verso sides of the first two and all of the third it would appear that the text relating to Peter Denrich continues, judging by the similarity of the hand and the various words that have survived.
Written bottom left to top right across the page.

msItem.title: Hymn to the Virgin
msItem.note: (17 strophes)
msItem.incipit: Sublestis prebe

msItem.author: Sibellinus Rorbach
msItem.title: Hymn
msItem.incipit: Singen springen der werlde lauff / tempore presenti / lygen vnd drygen ist er auch / constat mee menti
msItem.explicit: Bach der gnaden vnd edel schryn / miseris succurre / wan vns der duvel doyt groyß pyn / tu nobis occurre ·
msItem.note: Written bottom left to top right across the page. Fol. 220v begins with a Marian Latin hymn, which is followed, after a space, by a six-strophe macaronic hymn. The hymns continue in Latin on fol. 221r and finish on the stub which is 222r. They are written in a 15th century bastard hand, in black ink; the scribe has added some musical staves and melody on 221r. At the end the hymns are signed ‘Sibellinus rorbach genitus in Sygen’ (fol. 222r). (Mossman, c. 2003).
(macaronic: Latin and German)

On the recto side of the first stub is a macaronic hymn, in a different, cursive hand to that which transmitted the earlier hymns that are fully extant. Inc: Satiros non vereor / ich armes dulles wicht / ergo crucem mereor / daz ich doch halden licht /. The rest of the text is obviously cut away.
Similarly the recto side of the second stub contains a German hymn, in the same hand: Sicherlich in rüwen / begin ich sere czü gan / vnd gude werk czü buwen. The rest of the text is cut away.

The fourth stub is blank on the recto side but contains a scrap of German verse on the verso side, in a tiny cursive hand: Ach nu ach nu spade vnd layt vns daz wol bedencken · daz myr myt sunden crencken ·
The fifth stub is barely extant, and contains no text.

layoutDesc.layout: Text of Boethius typically long 16 lines per page, with space for interlinear glossing, in a written area of c. 160 80
The German translation written around the Latin text in 'textus inclusus', occupying the remaining space of the page.
The commentary on two columns of c. 54 lines, written space c. 190 120

msItem.author: Alanus ab Insula
msItem.title: De planctu naturae
msItem.note: (extract)
msItem.incipit: cogeret obliuisci locis fluuialibus emergentes
msItem.finalRubric: Hec ex alano facta sunt in laudem domini iesu

msItem.note: Theological notes
msItem.incipit: Nota 4 ducunt nos ad penitentiam

msItem.note: On Joachim of Fiore and Hildegard of Bingen, chiefly extracts from Vincent of Beauvais, Speculum historiale .
msItem.incipit: De abbate Ioachim ut legitur in speculo historiale vincentii parte tercia
Sancta hildegardis de tempore muliebri prophetavit in hunc modum

msItem.title: Apocalypse with commentary and glosses
msItem.incipit: Apocalipsis Ihesu Christi quam dedit illi Deus palam facere seruis suis
Apocalypsis id est revelatio Jesu id est salvatoris
Nota tribulatio est speciale donum quo dotantur electi
msItem.note: Interlinear and marginal commentary, including for example commentary on precious and semiprecious stones on fols. 275r-277r (fol. 276v blank).
Prologue to Apocalypse (cf. Stegmüller, Bibl. 834)
msItem.incipit: Iohannes apostolus et ewangelista a christo electus atque dilectus
msItem.explicit: vt nescientibus inquirendi detur occasio et querentibus merces laboris

msItem.title: Office of the Dead with commentary (fragment)

msItem.incipit: Parce michi domine nichil enim
msItem.note: The first reading, Job 7.16b-21, with beginning of the responsory 'Redemptor meus vivit'

msItem.incipit: Sancta et salubris est cogitatio pro defunctis ut a peccatis soluantur Machab 12 Innocentius. sanguinis Iesus Christi preciosissimus qui in remissionem peccatorum pro multis effusus est non solum ad salutem viventium
msItem.note: cf. Innocent III, De missarum mysteriis (PL 217.891)
Imperfect, followed by the stub of another folio of text; fol. 281v has been inked over.

msItem.author: Giles of Rome
msItem.title: De regimine principum
msItem.note: (abbreviation or adaptation)
msItem.incipit: Virtus est duplex scilicet infusa et acquisita. Augustinus. Virtus est bona qualitas
Anima in sedendo et quiescendo sit prudens. Iustitia est duplex scilicet legalis et equalis. Legalis iustitia est quid generale et quodammodo omnis virtus
msItem.explicit: videlicet bonitas amicitia et sapientia ut consulant recte bene et sapienter
msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis huius operis deo gracias
msItem.note: Fols. 282r-301r, cf. Giles of Rome I.ii.9-I.iii.11; fols. 301r-307v, cf. I.i.1-I.i.12; fols. 307v-319ar, cf. I.iv.1–7, 18, 23; II.ii.5–6, 10, 13; III.ii.17, 18. The prologue does not derive from Giles.
Verses

msItem.title: Carmen de presbitero et gallo
msItem.incipit: Multi sunt presbiteri qui ignorant quare
msItem.note: Hans Rheinfelder, 'Materialien zu dem mittelalterlichen Gedicht "Multi sunt presbyteri"', Zeitschrift für romanische Philologie (1951), 125–130, here stanzas 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 12, 11, 15, 18, 19, 22.

msItem.title: ‘Condiciones boni predicatoris’
msItem.incipit: Gestum compone non protrahe nec celer esto
msItem.note: Five verses; Charland, Artes Praedicandi, p. 100
Verses on the number of Christ's wounds
msItem.incipit: Mente nota tristi tu quot sunt wlnera christi
msItem.note: Three verses

msItem.incipit: Dic homo mortalis fuit unquam passio talis
msItem.note: Three verses
Fol. 319bv blank.

msItem.title: De mysteriis ecclesiae
msItem.note: (adaptation / extracts)
msItem.incipit:
Ecclesia est domus dei que in celis construitur ex viuis lapidibus quadratis et rotundis
Petra fundati et basis est petra Christi
Parietes circumstantes populus Iudei et gentiles a Christo informati per 4 partes mundi
msItem.explicit: quod Christus discipulos iussit vigilare et orare
msItem.note: In places varying considerably from Garland's text, in places very close to it; ends at l. 582–3 as ed. F. W. Otto, Commentariii critici in codicis bibliothecae academiae Gissensis (Giessen 1842), pp. 147; cf. fol. 367r below.
Notes on the Mass, priesthood, etc., including verses (the first two from Ps.-Bernard, Floretus):
msItem.incipit:
In cena summum Christus statuit sacramentum
Sub panis specie cum discipulis tribuit se
Dant ornamenta tibi presbiter hec documenta
Salue saluator mundi rex atque creator
O sangwis christi qui fusus amore fuisti
(fol. 321v) Nota sex sunt casus duplicandi missam licite

msItem.note: On the seven virtues

msItem.incipit: Apprehendent vij mulieres virum unum Ysa iiij 1 Ecce matrimonium amabile honorabile et nobile inter septenarium virtutum
Sapientia edificavit sibi domum excidit in ea columnas septem Prov. xj 1 Domum conscientie cuiuslibet fidelis et iusti hominis firmat deus septenario virtutum et gratiarum que sunt iste

msItem.note: On hospitality
msItem.incipit: Hospitalitem nolite obliuisci Heb. 13 Nota in veteri et novo testamentis habemus multa exempla inducenda nos ad amorem hospitalitatis

msItem.note: On dying
msItem.incipit: Mors peccatorum pessima preciosa autem in conspectu domini mors sanctorum eius. Beati mortui qui in domino moriuntur ideo disce mori. Incipe bene et iuste viuere si vis bene mori.

msItem.title: Cordiale quatuor nouissimorum
msItem.incipit: Memorare nouissima tua Augustinus in suis meditacionibus Plus vitanda est sola peccati feditas quam quelibet tormentorum immanitas. Bernardus in quoddam sermone In omnibus operibus
msItem.note: As pr. [c. 1471] (GW 7469), here abbreviated in places. Secundum novissimorum, fol. 338r; tercium, fol. 348v; quartum, fol. 358v.
Extracts from Augustine, Gregory, Bernard.
On the Virgin Mary, the Annunciation and the Incarnation
msItem.incipit: Beata virgo maria offerabatur 3º anno natiuitatis sue in templo et mansit inibi usque ad xiiij
Salve festa dies que wlnera nostra coercet
(fol. 365v) Venit dominus nascens in mundum ut quidam ayunt completis ab adam quinque milibus ducentis viginto octo annis
Anselmus 4 modis potest deus hominem facere
Iungitur vnda mero confecto sangwine christi
msItem.note: Extracts from John of Garland, De mysteriis, lines 570–5, 607, 595–8, 604–5, 608–15, 620–3, in Otto's edition.

msItem.author: John of Garland
msItem.title: De mysteriis ecclesiae
msItem.note: (epilogue)
msItem.incipit: Gemma pudicitiae fuit hic flos philosophiae
msItem.finalRubric: Hec misteriam scribit de Allexandro Johannes de Garlandeia in Summa misteriorum.
msItem.note: Ed. F. W. Otto, Commentariii critici in codicis bibliothecae academiae Gissensis (Giessen 1842), pp. 147–48.

supportDesc.foliation: Earlier foliation in arabic numerals 1–145, in brown ink, starting from current fol. 224.

layoutDesc.layout: Text of the Apocalypse c. 13–14 long lines, with space for interlinear glossing, in a written area of c. 155–60 75–85 ; a marginal column of 35 mm. for commentary, the commentary as written also extending into the upper and lower margins.
Fols. 282–368: usually 1 col., c. 43 lines, c. 195 115
